description: Skype for Business is the popular communications platform from Microsoft that can do so much more than just instant message. This course covers everything from installing Skype for Business to running an online, collaborative meeting. Other topics include managing contacts, conducting video and audio calls,  placing phone calls and  managing phone settings, and using collaboration tools such as screen sharing, whiteboards, and polls. This course is specifically for locally installed Skype for Business 2016 client on a Windows operating system.
descriptionMD: Skype for Business is the popular communications platform from Microsoft that can do so much more than just instant message. This course covers everything from installing Skype for Business to running an online, collaborative meeting. Other topics include managing contacts, conducting video and audio calls,  placing phone calls and  managing phone settings, and using collaboration tools such as screen sharing, whiteboards, and polls. This course is specifically for locally installed Skype for Business 2016 client on a Windows operating system.
name: Skype for Business
subtitle: Collaboration tool for real-time input

episodes.description: Skype for Business is the popular communications platform from Microsoft that can do so much more than just instant message. This course covers everything from installing Skype for Business to running an online, collaborative meeting. Other topics include managing contacts, conducting video and audio calls,  placing phone calls and  managing phone settings, and using collaboration tools such as screen sharing, whiteboards, and polls. This course is specifically for locally installed Skype for Business 2016 client on a Windows operating system.
episodes.title: Overview

episodes.description: Welcome to Skype for Business 2016! In this episode, Justin and Vonne introduce the course and the  foundational knowledge needed to understand Skype for Business. They differentiate Skype for Business from Skype, discuss Office 365 subscription plans and services, review versions and history of the application, and the overall setup for this course.
episodes.title: Introduction to Skype for Business

episodes.description: Installing the Skype for Business client is the the first step to using this communcations platform. In this episode, Vonne and Daniel discuss how to install the client as part of the Office 365 applications or as a stand alone installation.
episodes.title: Install Skype for Business

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne cover how to sign-in to a Skype for Business account with the correct credentials. Once signed in, they explore the interface covering presence, location, and different areas of the options dialog box. They also explain the difference between closing and exiting Skype for Business.
episodes.title: Sign-in and Interface

episodes.description: Setting up audio and video devices can be frustrating. In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne show where to find audio and video settings in Skype for Business as well as some ways to troubleshoot devices in the Windows operating system.
episodes.title: Setup and Troubleshoot Audio and Video Devices

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Ronnie discuss contacts in Skype for Business.  They show how to search for users, add contacts, create groups to organize contacts, and delete contacts.  They emphasize the difference between Skype for Business and Skype users and limitations on search results.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne explain the different status options in Skype for Business. They cover inactive and away, do not disturb, offline, and out of office. They also cover how to tag for status change alerts.
episodes.title: Status and Options

387
00:21:23.990 --> 00:21:27.743
It's one of those I hate to say it,
you kinda just have to live with it and

388
00:21:27.743 --> 00:21:30.570
just be like hey are you there,
don't get anything.

389
00:21:30.570 --> 00:21:31.903
All right I guess you're not there.

390
00:21:31.903 --> 00:21:35.889
[LAUGH] One of those, so
different ways of our statuses and

391
00:21:35.889 --> 00:21:41.630
then we could go ahead and we've seen
some of the ones that have changed.

392
00:21:41.630 --> 00:21:46.499
Now the thing that popped up
that we kinda maybe blipped is

393
00:21:46.499 --> 00:21:50.260
you can tag somebody for
a change of status.

394
00:21:50.260 --> 00:21:55.976
And that's what I did for JT,
I tagged Marisha for her status change.

395
00:21:55.976 --> 00:21:57.356
Because I know she's in and

396
00:21:57.356 --> 00:22:00.426
out like always kind of doing
all sorts of different things.

397
00:22:00.426 --> 00:22:05.590
So I can get a little alert when
somebody's status has changed.

398
00:22:05.590 --> 00:22:08.270
So let's go how about Ronnie, right?

399
00:22:08.270 --> 00:22:11.653
I will tag you for a status change alert.

400
00:22:11.653 --> 00:22:16.413
So on my end, that me as JT I
wanna see what's gonna happen.

401
00:22:16.413 --> 00:22:19.967
So let's also go ahead and
change your status and

402
00:22:19.967 --> 00:22:23.011
let's take me of the screen for a second.

403
00:22:23.011 --> 00:22:27.446
So we can see it happen in that bottom
right hand corner is that I've gone ahead

404
00:22:27.446 --> 00:22:30.100
and you set it to busy, right?

405
00:22:30.100 --> 00:22:34.925
So now you should be able to go ahead and
set it back to available Ronnie.

406
00:22:34.925 --> 00:22:38.229
[SOUND] There,
that's what I was looking for.

407
00:22:38.229 --> 00:22:39.996
So you can see that I have tagged,

408
00:22:39.996 --> 00:22:42.660
notice it didn't tag me
when you were busy did it?

409
00:22:42.660 --> 00:22:45.550
>> Nope.
>> It only tagged me when you became

410
00:22:45.550 --> 00:22:47.060
available again.

411
00:22:47.060 --> 00:22:49.903
So that's something that hey
if you're kinda waiting for

412
00:22:49.903 --> 00:22:51.536
the boss to get out of the office.

413
00:22:51.536 --> 00:22:54.358
>> Well actually out of a meeting so
you could talk to them,

414
00:22:54.358 --> 00:22:55.809
let's switch that around.

415
00:22:55.809 --> 00:22:57.639
[LAUGH]
>> You could go ahead and tag for

416
00:22:57.639 --> 00:22:59.659
their status of when
they become available.

417
00:22:59.659 --> 00:23:03.600
You'll get a little pop up and it will
let you know that that's what's going on.

418
00:23:03.600 --> 00:23:06.570
So that's how you can go ahead and
tag people.

419
00:23:06.570 --> 00:23:12.375
So lots of different things that
we can see within our status.

420
00:23:12.375 --> 00:23:16.770
Talked about those options that we went
over of when you want to go ahead and

421
00:23:16.770 --> 00:23:22.098
determine when your Skype shows
you as inactive and, or away.

422
00:23:22.098 --> 00:23:26.000
On how many minutes you become
idle on your computer or

423
00:23:26.000 --> 00:23:29.020
not using it, and
then that Do Not Disturb.

424
00:23:30.400 --> 00:23:32.435
Again remember those reverts,

425
00:23:32.435 --> 00:23:40.500
Busy and Do Not Disturb,
that's what I was trying to do.

426
00:23:40.500 --> 00:23:44.760
It will reset itself in 24 hours,
so if you're relying on that for

427
00:23:44.760 --> 00:23:47.920
multiple days, just watch it.

428
00:23:47.920 --> 00:23:52.460
Because all of these different reasons
of why you have your contacts and

429
00:23:52.460 --> 00:23:56.190
why you wanna look for
their status is kind of important.

430
00:23:56.190 --> 00:24:01.830
And we'll take this one step further
with our privacy settings or

431
00:24:01.830 --> 00:24:08.330
relationships to see how much I can and
cannot see with our different things.

432
00:24:08.330 --> 00:24:12.210
So I believe we're gonna go ahead and stop
right there Ronnie, with our status and

433
00:24:12.210 --> 00:24:12.750
options.

434
00:24:12.750 --> 00:24:16.088
And like I said we'll come back with
just a little bit more with contacts.

435
00:24:16.088 --> 00:24:19.120
>> All right Vonne, thank you again for
helping us to understand

436
00:24:19.120 --> 00:24:23.740
those different status messages that
we see in Skype a little bit better.

437
00:24:23.740 --> 00:24:28.085
And also seeing that even though we can
change them on the fly when we need to.

438
00:24:28.085 --> 00:24:32.635
There are some of those particular
statuses that we may end up seeing that

439
00:24:32.635 --> 00:24:35.405
are due to the fact that
we have a phone call.

440
00:24:35.405 --> 00:24:39.330
Or that we may also be in a presentation,
we may be sharing our screen.

441
00:24:39.330 --> 00:24:42.749
These are things that Skype for
Business is gonna pick up automatically.

442
00:24:42.749 --> 00:24:47.013
And help us out to allow for other
people to see what status that we are.

443
00:24:47.013 --> 00:24:50.145
And that way they won't disturb us in
the middle of an important phone call, or

444
00:24:50.145 --> 00:24:51.243
during the presentation.

445
00:24:51.243 --> 00:24:54.767
Or something that we really say l
need to spend some time here and

446
00:24:54.767 --> 00:24:57.242
l'll get back to them
a little bit later on.

447
00:24:57.242 --> 00:25:00.175
All right Vonne well that's
a great place for us to end.

448
00:25:00.175 --> 00:25:03.212
But before we do any last words for
everybody watching?

449
00:25:03.212 --> 00:25:06.827
>> I think this is gonna be the moral of
the story here with Skype for Business.

450
00:25:06.827 --> 00:25:09.605
Is there's always gonna be some
weird nuances that's gonna come up.

451
00:25:09.605 --> 00:25:12.603
That it's gonna be like I can't see this,

452
00:25:12.603 --> 00:25:16.865
I honestly have no reason why but
it just happens sometimes.

453
00:25:16.865 --> 00:25:21.372
So you hate to kinda throw that out, of
like this is how it's supposed to work but

454
00:25:21.372 --> 00:25:22.825
if it doesn't, sorry.

455
00:25:22.825 --> 00:25:26.500
[LAUGH] It does,
it's the nature of computers.

456
00:25:26.500 --> 00:25:28.712
>> All right,
well that is a world wide system and

457
00:25:28.712 --> 00:25:30.560
we do have to deal with it as well.

458
00:25:30.560 --> 00:25:33.120
But it is a great place for
us to sign off.

459
00:25:33.120 --> 00:25:36.330
For OfficeProTV I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

460
00:25:36.330 --> 00:25:37.300
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

461
00:25:37.300 --> 00:25:40.900
>> Stay tuned right here for
more of the Skype for Business episodes.

462
00:25:40.900 --> 00:25:46.430
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Ronnie explore privacy relationships and contact cards in Skype for Business.  They explain how to access a contact card and the options for editing the information as well as how it's tied to Outlook.  They also explore the different categories of privacy relationships and how to assign relationship to contacts.
episodes.title: Contact Cards and Privacy Relationships
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.361 --> 00:00:15.831
Welcome to another great episode,
right here, on OFFICEPRO.TV.

3
00:00:15.831 --> 00:00:18.290
You're watching the Skype for
Business show.

4
00:00:18.290 --> 00:00:19.830
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:19.830 --> 00:00:23.310
And today we're gonna be taking
a look at contact cards and

6
00:00:23.310 --> 00:00:26.370
our privacy relationships
inside of Skype For Business.

7
00:00:26.370 --> 00:00:31.284
And here to help us out, of course, is
our, well, Office Pro prodigy herself, Ms.

8
00:00:31.284 --> 00:00:32.195
Vonne Smith.

9
00:00:32.195 --> 00:00:33.840
Vonne, welcome back to the show.

10
00:00:33.840 --> 00:00:34.600
>> Ooh, prodigy.

11
00:00:34.600 --> 00:00:35.490
>> That's right, prodigy.

12
00:00:35.490 --> 00:00:36.220
>> That's a new one [LAUGH].

13
00:00:36.220 --> 00:00:38.800
>> Yes, all right, so Vonne, here it is.

14
00:00:38.800 --> 00:00:42.640
We've gotten to be able to play
with the status a little bit.

15
00:00:42.640 --> 00:00:44.750
We've also added contacts in.

16
00:00:44.750 --> 00:00:45.810
We were able to find them.

17
00:00:45.810 --> 00:00:48.660
We've gotten everything set
up the way that we want to.

18
00:00:48.660 --> 00:00:53.240
But now we're moving into this realm
of contact cards of relationships.

19
00:00:53.240 --> 00:00:54.280
What's that all about, Vonne?

20
00:00:54.280 --> 00:00:56.600
>> All right, well,
we have a contact card.

21
00:00:56.600 --> 00:00:59.410
It's kinda like your business card,
if you wanna say.

22
00:00:59.410 --> 00:01:04.160
It's one of those things that you
can go ahead and make for yourself.

23
00:01:04.160 --> 00:01:09.010
Well, actually, do you know about
the business card in Outlook?

24
00:01:09.010 --> 00:01:11.061
>> A little bit, yes,
I know exactly what that is.

25
00:01:11.061 --> 00:01:13.959
>> Yes, so that's where you
could go ahead and create your,

26
00:01:13.959 --> 00:01:16.518
it's like your own contact
within your contacts.

27
00:01:16.518 --> 00:01:22.500
And then you can attach it to your
Outlook signature as a business card.

28
00:01:22.500 --> 00:01:25.159
>> Right.
>> And that's one of those virtual VCFs,

29
00:01:25.159 --> 00:01:27.770
the different file formulas you can do.

30
00:01:27.770 --> 00:01:30.299
So it´s similar, it´s kinda like that.

31
00:01:30.299 --> 00:01:31.349
>> Mm-hm.

32
00:01:31.349 --> 00:01:32.431
>> And it´s kinda not [LAUGH].

33
00:01:32.431 --> 00:01:34.387
>> [LAUGH]
>> You know how it always goes.

34
00:01:34.387 --> 00:01:35.210
>> Sure, why not.

35
00:01:35.210 --> 00:01:36.210
>> Yeah, exactly.

36
00:01:36.210 --> 00:01:42.750
So it´s the information that
you can see on your contact.

37
00:01:42.750 --> 00:01:46.350
But it has a lot of nuances about it.

38
00:01:46.350 --> 00:01:50.519
Is it an internal contact
within your network?.

39
00:01:50.519 --> 00:01:52.267
If it's in your network,

40
00:01:52.267 --> 00:01:56.972
then those people are all in your
what I remember as Active Directory.

41
00:01:56.972 --> 00:01:58.946
>> Mm-hm.
>> Right, within your organization.

42
00:01:58.946 --> 00:02:04.166
All of the users that is controlled by
your Office 365 network administrators and

43
00:02:04.166 --> 00:02:07.337
things like that, so
we're all in the same place.

44
00:02:07.337 --> 00:02:12.662
So we can see a lot more information
about each other because of what

45
00:02:12.662 --> 00:02:17.812
is set at the top level and
how we can all kind of see that, right.

46
00:02:17.812 --> 00:02:20.776
You get into external contacts.

47
00:02:20.776 --> 00:02:22.993
Well, they're not in your network,

48
00:02:22.993 --> 00:02:26.266
so you're not gonna be able
to see maybe nearly as much.

49
00:02:26.266 --> 00:02:31.003
And their network administrators, or
however they go ahead and determine their

50
00:02:31.003 --> 00:02:35.753
organization, determines what people
outside of their organization can see.

51
00:02:35.753 --> 00:02:36.280
>> Right.
So

52
00:02:36.280 --> 00:02:41.770
that's why I say it all is very dependent
on all of these different nuances.

53
00:02:41.770 --> 00:02:46.371
So you might see a contact card for
one of your people in Skype,

54
00:02:46.371 --> 00:02:49.927
all sorts of stuff,
probably an internal one.

55
00:02:49.927 --> 00:02:54.459
You go to somebody who's an external
contact, you just might see their email.

56
00:02:54.459 --> 00:02:58.323
You might not see their address and
their different phone numbers and

57
00:02:58.323 --> 00:03:00.129
all of those different things.

58
00:03:01.520 --> 00:03:06.170
Then there's a whole other level
that gets into it is what is

59
00:03:06.170 --> 00:03:11.657
the privacy relationship that that
person has established with you?

60
00:03:11.657 --> 00:03:15.737
And that's something that we've kind
of mentioned throughout these different

61
00:03:15.737 --> 00:03:18.324
episodes when we're talking
about our contacts.

62
00:03:18.324 --> 00:03:20.960
And it does make a difference.

63
00:03:20.960 --> 00:03:24.690
And, especially, remember we were talking
about in the last episode, if you're

64
00:03:24.690 --> 00:03:29.700
watching in succession, we were talking
about the status and the options episode.

65
00:03:29.700 --> 00:03:32.700
We talked about that out of office status.

66
00:03:32.700 --> 00:03:35.991
And we couldn't get it to really work,
remember, right?

67
00:03:35.991 --> 00:03:37.461
>> Yeah, right.
And I had said, wait,

68
00:03:37.461 --> 00:03:39.409
I thought I set Joey as an out of office.

69
00:03:39.409 --> 00:03:42.137
And I'm like, well,
it still says he's available.

70
00:03:42.137 --> 00:03:48.360
And we kind of went back and forth on
that one and, well, [LAUGH] guess what?

71
00:03:48.360 --> 00:03:54.730
There's another aspect that we forgot
to set in all of these settings,

72
00:03:54.730 --> 00:03:59.060
and it's directly tied to
the privacy relationships.

73
00:03:59.060 --> 00:04:02.040
I'm gonna pull all that up, so
it's gonna come full circle

74
00:04:02.040 --> 00:04:05.830
with the out of office status and
the different things you can do.

75
00:04:05.830 --> 00:04:08.820
So let's go ahead and jump on into it.

76
00:04:08.820 --> 00:04:11.479
You can see I've got my Skype for
Business up.

77
00:04:11.479 --> 00:04:14.603
I've got a couple of people
that are either away, or

78
00:04:14.603 --> 00:04:17.238
unavailable, or those different things.

79
00:04:17.238 --> 00:04:18.675
You can see their statuses.

80
00:04:18.675 --> 00:04:21.610
[LAUGH] All right, contact cards.

81
00:04:21.610 --> 00:04:23.930
If I went ahead and went to Joey.

82
00:04:23.930 --> 00:04:27.838
Now, Joey right now is
in my internal contacts.

83
00:04:27.838 --> 00:04:31.270
If I right-click on him and
go to See Contact Card,

84
00:04:31.270 --> 00:04:35.660
I believe you can hover over their
picture and then come to here.

85
00:04:35.660 --> 00:04:37.050
Or is it that one?

86
00:04:37.050 --> 00:04:38.212
Is that the contact card?

87
00:04:38.212 --> 00:04:38.919
>> I believe it is.

88
00:04:38.919 --> 00:04:41.063
>> I believe, so okay, good [LAUGH].

89
00:04:41.063 --> 00:04:43.790
I was looking for
the hover to put the little tool tip up.

90
00:04:45.260 --> 00:04:48.910
Cuz, honestly, I usually just right-click,
then do the See Contact Card.

91
00:04:48.910 --> 00:04:50.230
So notice in Joey, and

92
00:04:50.230 --> 00:04:55.060
I'm kinda grabbing by the top,
I can see a lot of stuff in here.

93
00:04:55.060 --> 00:04:58.840
I can see, all right,
well he's obviously an Outlook contact.

94
00:04:58.840 --> 00:05:02.720
He's got a mobile number in there,
some notes in here.

95
00:05:02.720 --> 00:05:04.080
There's an organization.

96
00:05:04.080 --> 00:05:05.200
There's memberships.

97
00:05:05.200 --> 00:05:07.212
Look at the memberships
that he has right here.

98
00:05:07.212 --> 00:05:09.680
And these are the ones that
we have with groups, right.

99
00:05:09.680 --> 00:05:11.414
Cuz I think I made the reunion tour.

100
00:05:11.414 --> 00:05:13.560
I think you made the IT tier one?

101
00:05:13.560 --> 00:05:15.310
>> Right.
>> In one of your episodes.

102
00:05:15.310 --> 00:05:20.623
So I see a lot of different
things with Joey's contact card.

103
00:05:20.623 --> 00:05:22.203
He's an internal contact.

104
00:05:22.203 --> 00:05:27.395
If I go to Marisha's contact card,
right-click, that's all I see.

105
00:05:27.395 --> 00:05:31.800
[LAUGH] I don't really see much
more than that, except her email.

106
00:05:31.800 --> 00:05:33.713
I see something about a calendar.

107
00:05:33.713 --> 00:05:37.568
And, of course, I still have my other
buttons here for more ways that

108
00:05:37.568 --> 00:05:41.570

call them, and so on and so forth.

109
00:05:41.570 --> 00:05:49.290
So, again, internal and external contacts
are what we can see on the contact card.

110
00:05:49.290 --> 00:05:51.060
>> All right, so Vonne,
let me ask a question.

111
00:05:51.060 --> 00:05:53.170
Where is this information
being pulled from?

112
00:05:53.170 --> 00:05:56.570
Is this something when I sign in
to Skype that I need to set up?

113
00:05:56.570 --> 00:06:00.060
Or is this actually pulling
from my Office 365 account?

114
00:06:00.060 --> 00:06:04.175
>> It's pulling from your account,
but it's also really their account.

115
00:06:04.175 --> 00:06:06.170
>> Okay.
>> That's what it's showing.

116
00:06:06.170 --> 00:06:10.966
And, again, those privacy settings, as to
what they've determined of what I can see,

117
00:06:10.966 --> 00:06:12.928
that's on them.

118
00:06:12.928 --> 00:06:13.833
>> Mm-hm.

119
00:06:13.833 --> 00:06:16.550
You, for example, not me.

120
00:06:16.550 --> 00:06:19.880
I can go ahead and set all sorts
of different relationships, but

121
00:06:19.880 --> 00:06:21.650
that's how I am dealing with them.

122
00:06:23.380 --> 00:06:24.910
Turn it around, right?

123
00:06:24.910 --> 00:06:26.710
You set it how you're dealing with me.

124
00:06:26.710 --> 00:06:29.760
Okay, and we could go ahead and
establish that.

125
00:06:29.760 --> 00:06:32.327
So we'll come back to
that in just a second.

126
00:06:32.327 --> 00:06:36.444
But the other thing I wanted to
point out with those contact cards,

127
00:06:36.444 --> 00:06:40.135
if I bring up Joey's,
you see this button right over here.

128
00:06:40.135 --> 00:06:43.094
It says Edit contact.

129
00:06:43.094 --> 00:06:44.043
Is that mine?

130
00:06:44.043 --> 00:06:46.750
Let's come over here to Marisha's contact.

131
00:06:46.750 --> 00:06:49.342
It says Add, hm.

132
00:06:49.342 --> 00:06:53.890
Well, this is because Joey
is my Outlook contact.

133
00:06:53.890 --> 00:06:59.740
Marisha is not my Outlook contact,
two separate places.

134
00:06:59.740 --> 00:07:03.875
So if I wanted, if I've been talking
to Marisha through Skype and

135
00:07:03.875 --> 00:07:08.611
I wanna add her into my Outlook contacts
cuz I just want her over in my Outlook

136
00:07:08.611 --> 00:07:12.245
contacts [LAUGH], I could go ahead and
click that button.

137
00:07:12.245 --> 00:07:16.914
Notice that it's bringing up some
things that I can then add more

138
00:07:16.914 --> 00:07:19.686
information into it that I want to do.

139
00:07:19.686 --> 00:07:24.979
And we've talked about this in our Outlook
shows is that a global address list,

140
00:07:24.979 --> 00:07:26.007
you have your.

141
00:07:26.007 --> 00:07:27.975
We just talked about the Active Directory,
right.

142
00:07:27.975 --> 00:07:30.135
Right.
>> Internally it has all this information.

143
00:07:30.135 --> 00:07:36.858
But maybe I wanna add some more stuff in
my local contacts, my set of contacts.

144
00:07:36.858 --> 00:07:39.428
Not my global addresses,
my contacts in Outlook.

145
00:07:39.428 --> 00:07:41.762
To add things like maybe a birthday or

146
00:07:41.762 --> 00:07:45.904
different levels of notes that I
need to know that this particular

147
00:07:45.904 --> 00:07:49.690
person is more than just what
the global address list says.

148
00:07:49.690 --> 00:07:52.307
And this is the same kind of idea.

149
00:07:52.307 --> 00:07:56.850
I can add in more information into my
Outlook contacts rather than my Skype

150
00:07:56.850 --> 00:07:57.590
contacts.

151
00:07:57.590 --> 00:08:02.719
And, notice, I can just say Work address,

episodes.description: Vonne and Ronnie start communicating with contacts via instant message (IM).  They show how to start an instant message with a contact and explore the IM interface as well as options for messages such as important, emoticons, and links.  They also demonstrate how to send and receive attachments and the default location for saved files.
episodes.title: Instant Message: Basics

what can actually happen.

637
00:32:57.160 --> 00:32:59.100
And of course some of
the different things you can do,

638
00:32:59.100 --> 00:33:03.560
such as adding in attachments or
even sending links, changing the size,

639
00:33:03.560 --> 00:33:06.850
especially if you need to see
more of it instead of smaller.

640
00:33:06.850 --> 00:33:10.360
You can make it smaller, but I would
have a hard time seeing it as well.

641
00:33:10.360 --> 00:33:15.340
But this is one of those communication
tools that is available for

642
00:33:15.340 --> 00:33:18.490
us and we're going to see it probably
being used more often as well.

643
00:33:18.490 --> 00:33:21.970
All right, Vonne, well, since we've
actually kind of gone over everything,

644
00:33:21.970 --> 00:33:24.990
this is a great place for
us to end this episode then.

645
00:33:24.990 --> 00:33:29.030
Signing off for OfficeProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

646
00:33:29.030 --> 00:33:29.980
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

647
00:33:29.980 --> 00:33:33.473
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Skype for Business episodes.

648
00:33:33.473 --> 00:33:37.692
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, the team demonstrates how to manage multiple instant messages. They explore the tabbed conversation interface, copy and paste between conversations, and how to add people into messages to create a group conversation.
episodes.title: Manage Multiple Instant Messages

Apply settings to incoming messages.

But if I'm here in my multiple chats, like

00:10:01.680 --> 00:10:07.420
in, let's go with,

That was supposed to be

Blue for you, and

By changing that options,

Like for example,

I always go over here when

The last one it looks like,

So if I said Close current tab,

Also notice that you have

It's like, hey, stop asking me.

00:11:46.160 --> 00:11:49.780
I know better, if I click that top
x it's gonna close everything down.

212
00:11:50.860 --> 00:11:54.769
I tend to forget,
because I'm usually doing shortcuts for

So if he starts typing and I'm typing with

So maybe actually Ronnie,

Can we go ahead and

So I'm in this one conversation,

Notice right there I have

00:24:41.600 --> 00:24:45.590

00:24:45.590 --> 00:24:46.720

00:24:55.983 --> 00:24:59.612

00:24:59.612 --> 00:25:01.760
That just lets you know

in the tabs that somebody else is talking

00:25:06.135 --> 00:25:09.175

Back into our group chat, what if I

So notice that I brought

Yes, it's still a conversation, we're

If I wanted to, let's say remove Marisha,

472
00:25:56.563 --> 00:26:00.150
Yes, so now you can see that I've

473
00:26:00.150 --> 00:26:03.650
>> And Vonne,
on Joey's end right here on his computer,

00:26:03.650 --> 00:26:06.790
there's a yellow bar that appears that

00:26:06.790 --> 00:26:09.952
>> Yeah, so you do get a status update

00:26:09.952 --> 00:26:11.896
about you start a group chat-
>> Let's see.

477
00:26:11.896 --> 00:26:17.892
>> With me, and then we can see it as

00:26:17.892 --> 00:26:21.064
what that actually looks like so.

479
00:26:21.064 --> 00:26:24.685
And I've decided that we're gonna go
ahead and close this conversation out, so

00:26:24.685 --> 00:26:26.030
I'm going to close that tab.

481
00:26:27.760 --> 00:26:28.920
Also, now okay,

482
00:26:28.920 --> 00:26:32.390
I've got it just behind my head you can

So that's another thing that you

So I know automatically that this

486
00:26:44.490 --> 00:26:47.105
So I'll go ahead and accept that, and

00:26:47.105 --> 00:26:51.123
I can see that I have been

488
00:26:51.123 --> 00:26:54.320
And I'm just gonna go ahead and

489
00:26:54.320 --> 00:26:58.499
Notice that we've got,

00:26:58.499 --> 00:27:01.909
I know that I'm on the group,

491
00:27:01.909 --> 00:27:05.520
And I can still click on this

492
00:27:06.720 --> 00:27:09.548
When we get into if you don't

we can talk about attendees and

494
00:27:13.126 --> 00:27:16.863
So Ronnie, why don't you go ahead and

So would you go ahead and

I was removed from the meeting,

So now you can see that that's what

So different things to look at when

I think I have a couple more up here.

00:27:36.840 --> 00:27:39.659
So how you can manage multiple chats or

00:27:39.659 --> 00:27:43.544

The copy and past and

then it's usually down at the bottom.

505
00:27:50.756 --> 00:27:54.432
And then you can go ahead and click it and

506
00:27:54.432 --> 00:27:56.818
Again it might be over towards the left,

00:27:56.818 --> 00:27:57.673
that would be the right.

508
00:27:57.673 --> 00:27:59.050
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

>> Of where it's kinda giving you little

00:28:01.205 --> 00:28:06.195
buttons and then right here, it also gives

511
00:28:06.195 --> 00:28:09.136
You'll see this in the conversation for
Skype for Business.

512
00:28:09.136 --> 00:28:13.762
And you'll also see this in Outlook which

00:28:13.762 --> 00:28:15.580

514
00:28:15.580 --> 00:28:17.800
So I'm gonna go ahead and
close all of them.

515
00:28:17.800 --> 00:28:23.490
Yes, I do wanna close all my chats and

00:28:23.490 --> 00:28:29.010
it's a lot of window management, just

517
00:28:29.010 --> 00:28:32.570
And hey, really more before

518
00:28:32.570 --> 00:28:35.752
Am I in the right chat-

519
00:28:35.752 --> 00:28:41.104
>> With the right person, understanding
how groups do change a little bit.

520
00:28:41.104 --> 00:28:44.455
And then you can control more options
from there because you really do

00:28:44.455 --> 00:28:45.270
have a meeting.

522
00:28:45.270 --> 00:28:49.853
So I believe we've covered everything

523
00:28:49.853 --> 00:28:51.625
>> Well thank you again, Vonne, for

00:28:51.625 --> 00:28:54.580
helping us to understand
this a little bit better.

It is easy to think just because we know

When we start chatting with multiple

So Vonne has showed us we've gotta be

And the options that are available there,

533
00:29:19.530 --> 00:29:23.270
So this is a great place for

00:29:23.270 --> 00:29:26.880
Signing off for OfficeProTV,

536
00:29:27.830 --> 00:29:32.086
>> Stay tuned right here for

537
00:29:32.086 --> 00:29:39.600

episodes.description: Vonne and Ronnie continue their discussion about conversations, specifically covering missed conversations, do not disturb, and deleting conversations.  They explain how conversations are connected to Outlook in the conversation history folder as well as administrative settings for networks.
episodes.title: Manage Instant Message Conversations
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

2

Welcome to another great episode

You're watching the Skype for
Business show.

we're gonna be taking a look at the idea

5

message conversations.

6

And here to help us,

Miss Vonne Smith.

8

Vonne, welcome back to the show,
how are you doing?

9

>> It was almost like, wait, did he pause?

00:00:37.200 --> 00:00:37.720
>> I did.

11
00:00:37.720 --> 00:00:39.630
>> Did we freeze frame for a second?

12

>> Yes, we did.
>> You're really good at that.

13
00:00:40.537 --> 00:00:41.263
>> Yes.

14

>> Yeah.

15
00:00:42.010 --> 00:00:46.374
>> All right, Vonne, so here we are,
we're at this idea where we've now taken

00:00:46.374 --> 00:00:50.873
a look at using instant messaging between

multiple users inside of a group chat and

But now we're talking about the idea

>> Yeah, this is an episode that I wanted

And then, we're gonna talk a little bit

26
00:01:25.920 --> 00:01:33.125
[LAUGH] And where can I go and delete my
instant messages and is it really gone?

27
00:01:33.125 --> 00:01:35.120
[LAUGH] So,
we'll have a little conversation,

28
00:01:35.120 --> 00:01:37.126
we'll have an actual conversation-
>> Okay.

29
00:01:37.126 --> 00:01:38.480
>> About that-
>> Sounds good.

30
00:01:38.480 --> 00:01:41.570
>> So, why don't we start with
the missed conversations,

31
00:01:41.570 --> 00:01:44.750
it's just like if somebody called you and

32
00:01:44.750 --> 00:01:48.930
It's on my phone, I have a little button
at the bottom, where I'm in my phone,

33
00:01:48.930 --> 00:01:50.265
it has missed calls.

34
00:01:50.265 --> 00:01:51.970
>> Right.
>> So, I look at that and

35
00:01:51.970 --> 00:01:56.210
I can see that I've missed certain calls
and some I didn't answer on purpose,

36
00:01:56.210 --> 00:01:58.090
cuz I didn't wanna talk to that person or

37
00:01:58.090 --> 00:02:01.695
really, it's like, I don't recognize
that number, I'm not picking this up.

38
00:02:01.695 --> 00:02:04.200
[LAUGH] If it's important,
they'll leave a message.

39
00:02:04.200 --> 00:02:10.290
So, I kind of go with that model there,
Ronnie, I don't just pick up any phone.

40
00:02:10.290 --> 00:02:14.360
And usually, when I do,
it reinforces the fact that like, nope,

00:02:14.360 --> 00:02:16.410
this is why I don't answer
numbers I don't know about,

42
00:02:16.410 --> 00:02:18.350
cuz it's usually some telemarketer or

43
00:02:19.860 --> 00:02:23.070
So, if I have a missed conversation,
it's because,

44
00:02:23.070 --> 00:02:27.340
maybe, I'm not logged in and
somebody's messaging me.

45

And I'll still get it, I just don't see

46
00:02:32.198 --> 00:02:36.946
[LAUGH] Why don't we jump down

47
00:02:36.946 --> 00:02:41.773
you can see that I've got it to where
I signed out of Skype and I know,

48
00:02:41.773 --> 00:02:43.837

49
00:02:43.837 --> 00:02:48.533
[LAUGH] I had Joey Skype
our instant message JT, so,

50
00:02:48.533 --> 00:02:54.105
when I sign in what's gonna happen
is I get a little red number

51
00:02:54.105 --> 00:03:01.260
up there that's just saying, that,
hey, I got a missed conversation.

52
00:03:01.260 --> 00:03:03.930
So, if I click on this and
it also, hovers, it says,

53
00:03:03.930 --> 00:03:06.500
I have one missed conversation and

00:03:06.500 --> 00:03:11.460
you can see, that I've actually got

55
00:03:11.460 --> 00:03:16.130
Nope, nope missed [LAUGH] cuz
I control that computer, too.

56
00:03:16.130 --> 00:03:18.970
So, I've got Joe and it says,
hey, wanna grab coffee?

57
00:03:18.970 --> 00:03:20.820
I've got the little red dump number here,

58
00:03:20.820 --> 00:03:23.690
so, if I have a lot of them,
they'll go ahead and give me that.

59
00:03:23.690 --> 00:03:28.180
If I open this up,
I can double click it and

60
00:03:28.180 --> 00:03:33.160
I can go ahead and respond and
be like, I'm back and I could say,

61
00:03:33.160 --> 00:03:37.080
like, sure, after the show.

62
00:03:37.080 --> 00:03:41.030
And now, I've gone ahead and
started the conversation back up with it.

63
00:03:41.030 --> 00:03:45.970
So, you can open up your missed
conversations right from that particular

64
00:03:45.970 --> 00:03:51.058
tab within our Skype for Business and we
can go ahead and start our conversation.

65
00:03:51.058 --> 00:03:56.154
Wonderful, so, now,
this is something that Joey

66
00:03:56.154 --> 00:04:00.910
actually saw when he theoretically,

67
00:04:00.910 --> 00:04:06.140
went ahead and did all this,
because you have your statuses,

68
00:04:06.140 --> 00:04:10.060
let's go look over here at my contacts.

69
00:04:10.060 --> 00:04:16.190
If I go into this one, like, I know
that I'm not logged in right now on my

70
00:04:16.190 --> 00:04:22.210
regular ITProTV account, so, you can see,
it says, Offline, not online,

71
00:04:22.210 --> 00:04:27.020
so, that shows me an indication that
this person's not gonna receive it, but

72
00:04:27.020 --> 00:04:31.420
let me go ahead and open this up and
try to chat, but it says, look,

73
00:04:31.420 --> 00:04:36.824
Vonne Smith is offline, but they'll
still get your IMs as missed messages.

74
00:04:36.824 --> 00:04:41.215
Cool, so, you're being alerted
that it's still gonna get through,

75
00:04:41.215 --> 00:04:44.240
they are just not connected right now.

76
00:04:45.460 --> 00:04:50.280
So, you could see it on both sides
when you receive missed messages or

77
00:04:50.280 --> 00:04:53.630
if you're going to be sending
a message to somebody,

78
00:04:53.630 --> 00:04:56.400
that's gonna end up
being a missed message.

79
00:04:57.640 --> 00:05:02.190
And if they miss those,
then don't always fault them, but

80
00:05:02.190 --> 00:05:06.190
now you know that, hey, I know where
to look, in case somebody's like,

81
00:05:06.190 --> 00:05:10.314
hey, I went ahead and IMed you,

82
00:05:10.314 --> 00:05:13.181
I didn't see it, yeah, no,
you just didn't know where to look.

83
00:05:13.181 --> 00:05:14.194
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

84
00:05:14.194 --> 00:05:17.167
>> Or you on purpose didn't wanna,

85
00:05:17.167 --> 00:05:18.446
IM them back.

86
00:05:18.446 --> 00:05:21.550
[LAUGH] So, those are some of
the different things that happen.

87
00:05:21.550 --> 00:05:28.130
Now, the other thing that I wanna
cover in here is that, Do Not Disturb.

88
00:05:28.130 --> 00:05:30.150
>> Right.
>> That's kind of a big one.

89
00:05:30.150 --> 00:05:33.527
So, let's go ahead, I'm gonna start
a conversation with Joey, right and

90
00:05:33.527 --> 00:05:37.200
Joey's, were talking,
right and we're doing good.

91
00:05:37.200 --> 00:05:41.530
But, maybe, he went ahead and
saw that I chatted him and I would, if

92
00:05:41.530 --> 00:05:45.315
you don't mind, Ronnie, can you set Joey's
status to Do Not Disturb, right now?

93
00:05:45.315 --> 00:05:51.935
[LAUGH] Now, this might be another
indication that like, hey, do not disturb.

94
00:05:51.935 --> 00:05:55.395
Ooh, okay, I got it, loud and clear.

95
00:05:55.395 --> 00:06:00.210
[LAUGH] But look at what it says,
Joey has set the Do Not Disturb.

96
00:06:00.210 --> 00:06:07.435
Based on their settings, they may
still get your IMs as missed messages.

97
00:06:07.435 --> 00:06:12.962
[LAUGH] So, it's gonna go back into
the whole idea of they'll get it,

98
00:06:12.962 --> 00:06:16.210
but it'll be a missed message.

99
00:06:16.210 --> 00:06:17.570
But depending on their settings,

100
00:06:17.570 --> 00:06:19.910
that's why we talked about
our privacy relationships.

101
00:06:19.910 --> 00:06:25.300
You can have it to where people could
still get through to you, even though,

102
00:06:25.300 --> 00:06:30.390
you put the Do Not Disturb, but they
have to be in that work group setting.

103
00:06:30.390 --> 00:06:32.560
If they're in Colleagues, I think,
it's Colleagues, Friends and

104
00:06:32.560 --> 00:06:36.100
Family, in external, if they're in any
of those, they're not gonna get it.

105
00:06:36.100 --> 00:06:41.355
So, I could be like, okay,
got the message, Joey.

106
00:06:41.355 --> 00:06:47.460
[LAUGH] Maybe, frowny face and
now you can see that it's going through.

107
00:06:47.460 --> 00:06:52.065
One other thing I actually did forget
to mention in the basic episode,

108
00:06:52.065 --> 00:06:57.650
if you do things like the colon and

109
00:06:57.650 --> 00:07:03.102
then the parenthesis, like,
a regular smiley, it will send out

110
00:07:03.102 --> 00:07:08.260
as a smiley the same way as like,
a frown or a wink and things like that.

111
00:07:08.260 --> 00:07:12.955
So, those emoticons, they will
translate into some of those regular

112
00:07:12.955 --> 00:07:16.147
text based ones and
then we'll change into it.

113
00:07:16.147 --> 00:07:21.125
That is in a setting, like, if you turned
all of that off, like, I don't want to

114
00:07:21.125 --> 00:07:26.032
send little yellow faces, I want to have
the colon and the parenthesis, then go

115
00:07:26.032 --> 00:07:30.893
ahead and turn that setting off and so,
Joey will get this as a missed message.

116
00:07:30.893 --> 00:07:35.196
Or he might be getting them and
just not responding to me,

117
00:07:35.196 --> 00:07:38.871
because depending on his setting,
for me as JT,

118
00:07:38.871 --> 00:07:43.310
that's whether or
not it's going to come through.

119
00:07:43.310 --> 00:07:47.691
And just to kinda test that
out on the other end, right,

120
00:07:47.691 --> 00:07:50.312
I'm here as Justin Timberlake.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne discuss the difference between Skype calls and phone calls.  They explain how different subscription levels and additional services determine if a user can make phone calls with the Office 365 account.  They also take a look at the Admin center to better demonstrate these options.

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Ronnie demonstrate how to place and receive phone calls. They review the call window and how it differentiates between someone using the Skype client or a phone to receive a call. They also discuss how to transfer to a different device or phone.
episodes.title: Manage Phone Calls

episodes.description: Ronnie and Vonne go through the different options for phone settings in Skype for Business.  They review call forwarding, simultaneously ring, as well as how and when calls get redirected to voicemail. They also show how to setup voicemail, record a greeting, and access voicemails in Outlook.
episodes.title: Manage Phone Settings

episodes.description: Meeting face to face can enhance a conversation. In this episode, Vonne and INSERT demonstrate how to place and receive video calls in Skype for Business. They also cover troubleshooting common issues with video calls.
episodes.title: Video Calls

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne present the foundations of meetings in Skype for Business. They discuss the basics of scheduling a meeting, managing participants, using collaboration tools, and recording a meeting.
episodes.title: Introduction to Meetings

episodes.description: Vonne and Ronnie demonstrate how to schedule a meeting in Skype for Business through Outlook as an oganizer. They discuss the different meeting options such as how people enter the meeting, who is a presenter, and meeting interface.
episodes.title: Schedule a Meeting

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Ronnie demonstrate how to manage participants in the participant pane from the perspective of the meeting organizer when conducting a Skype for Business meeting. They show how to allow people in to the meeting from the lobby, change participant actions and status, and remove paticipants.
episodes.title: Manage Participants

episodes.description: Vonne and Ronnie demonstrate how to join a meeting as a participant.  They show how to enter a meeting from an email invite as well as Skype for Business.  They also discuss audio and video options, the participant pane, and layout options.
episodes.title: Join a Meeting

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Daniel show other ways to create and join meetings without being scheduled beforehand through Outlook.  They review options and how conversations turn into meetings by adding participants to an instant message and by sharing content. They also cover the Meet Now button and how to manage an impromptu meeting.
episodes.title: Start an Impromptu Meeting

episodes.description: Have people that are not able to attend the meeting? Send them a recording! In this episode, Justin and Vonne explain how to record a meeting and use the Skype for Business Recording Manager. They also discuss ways to distribute the recording.
episodes.title: Record a Meeting

episodes.description: Vonne and Ronnie dive into the collaboration section of the show starting with how to share your desktop or window during a Skype for Business meeting or conversation.  They also cover how to give control of your desktop or window to other users as well as how to request control from sharing their screen with you.
episodes.title: Share Your Desktop or Window

00:18:26.000 --> 00:18:29.080
If I double click again,
it's gonna take me out of it.

339
00:18:29.080 --> 00:18:33.985
So it's a quick way to come in and
out of full-screen mode in any of your

340
00:18:33.985 --> 00:18:39.060
conversations or in this case
collaborations with the desktop.

341
00:18:39.060 --> 00:18:42.140
>> Vonne I just saw something on
my screen that also matched yours.

342
00:18:42.140 --> 00:18:45.659
Which is I now have this border around
the edge of my entire screen and

343
00:18:45.659 --> 00:18:48.828
I'm also seeing it in the window
that you're seeing there.

344
00:18:48.828 --> 00:18:50.736
That kind of yellowish or gold or

345
00:18:50.736 --> 00:18:55.960
orange-ish border as well that shows me
at least visually that I'm sharing it.

346
00:18:55.960 --> 00:18:58.980
And the person on the other end is sharing
it, so it's a good visual indicator.

347
00:18:58.980 --> 00:19:00.430
>> Yes, definitely.

348
00:19:00.430 --> 00:19:02.128
And that's funny,
because I'm glad you pointed it out.

349
00:19:02.128 --> 00:19:05.466
Because yeah, I do see that [LAUGH].

350
00:19:05.466 --> 00:19:07.836
I couldn't remember that you did.

351
00:19:07.836 --> 00:19:11.200
All right, so the request control,
I can go ahead and click on this.

352
00:19:11.200 --> 00:19:13.381
And so, well,
actually allow me control, Ryan, so

353
00:19:13.381 --> 00:19:14.936
we can see what it looks like on my end.

354
00:19:14.936 --> 00:19:16.312
>> Sure, why not.

355
00:19:16.312 --> 00:19:17.930
>> Why not.

356
00:19:17.930 --> 00:19:22.470
All right, so now you can see that
on my end it says release control.

357
00:19:22.470 --> 00:19:26.540
So I can come in here and
I can start moving things around.

358
00:19:26.540 --> 00:19:30.280
Now this is where, okay,
you've gotta be kind of careful.

359
00:19:30.280 --> 00:19:33.570
And that's probably like I didn't
really mean to click on that button.

360
00:19:33.570 --> 00:19:39.317
And I can come down into here and
I can type in Edge, right?

361
00:19:39.317 --> 00:19:40.110
>> Mm-hm.

362
00:19:40.110 --> 00:19:44.804
>> So there we go, cuz maybe I wanna
go ahead and start your browser up.

363
00:19:44.804 --> 00:19:49.851
But you got to be very kind of, you got to
be patient, you got to kind of let your

364
00:19:49.851 --> 00:19:54.620
mouth, your mouse move to different
places, maybe I wanna close that.

365
00:19:54.620 --> 00:19:56.500
Again, we're on a really
strong connection, so

366
00:19:56.500 --> 00:19:58.090
our response time is pretty quick.

367
00:19:59.180 --> 00:20:01.970
But know, Marisha and I tested this out.

368
00:20:01.970 --> 00:20:06.014
And Marisha was like,
this is just like, it's too slow.

369
00:20:06.014 --> 00:20:10.014
There's so much lag that I was
actually a detriment to her and

370
00:20:10.014 --> 00:20:14.100
how we were supposed to be
communicating and collaborating.

371
00:20:14.100 --> 00:20:17.710
She was really just testing with me,
but she's like,

372
00:20:17.710 --> 00:20:22.575
if I was on a real meeting with this,
she goes, this would be More annoying

373
00:20:22.575 --> 00:20:27.538
[LAUGH] than helpful, so just be aware
of those things, it's always nice.

374
00:20:27.538 --> 00:20:31.174
Now I'll release the control, now as
it says, you no longer have control.

375
00:20:31.174 --> 00:20:34.674
[LAUGH] Sounds like the story of
my life sometimes, so [LAUGH].

376
00:20:34.674 --> 00:20:37.646
You can see all the different
options that we have here

377
00:20:37.646 --> 00:20:41.380
on the receiving end of having
something being shared with.

378
00:20:41.380 --> 00:20:46.440
I can't stop the sharing,
so I just can't do that.

379
00:20:46.440 --> 00:20:48.680
But he can, and that's a nice thing.

380
00:20:48.680 --> 00:20:52.530
I do like that we did this part right
here, is that he stopped sharing but

381
00:20:52.530 --> 00:20:55.570
I still see this stage, they call it.

382
00:20:55.570 --> 00:20:58.180
Where they're staging all the material.

383
00:20:58.180 --> 00:21:01.150
Well, I don't wanna really see that,
and I can still keep chatting.

384
00:21:01.150 --> 00:21:03.660
We can keep talking, but
I don't want that anymore.

385
00:21:03.660 --> 00:21:08.324
So I'm gonna go ahead and just, sorry,
I keep doing that, hide the stage.

386
00:21:08.324 --> 00:21:14.487
And then it just goes back to a normal
chat window, so that's something to do.

387
00:21:14.487 --> 00:21:19.400
Here, I'm just gonna share my screen
with you one more time just to

388
00:21:19.400 --> 00:21:23.990
give you all a quick little tip
that kind of threw me off, too.

389
00:21:23.990 --> 00:21:29.323
Is that I,
see where it says Show Stage right there?

390
00:21:29.323 --> 00:21:32.450
And this could be on either end,
whether I'm sharing or not sharing.

391
00:21:32.450 --> 00:21:35.520
But I hit it once and I couldn't find it.

392
00:21:35.520 --> 00:21:38.290
I think it's on the receiving end
like I was the one being shared.

393
00:21:38.290 --> 00:21:40.938
And I clicked this button
down at the bottom.

394
00:21:40.938 --> 00:21:43.080
Notice it says Hide Stage right now.

395
00:21:43.080 --> 00:21:44.900
And so maybe, Ronnie,
you'll see that we're talking about.

396
00:21:44.900 --> 00:21:45.970
And then it's like, whoa, wait.

397
00:21:45.970 --> 00:21:48.600
I, where did the person's screen go?

398
00:21:48.600 --> 00:21:52.823
So just in case your stage
goes away on either end,

399
00:21:52.823 --> 00:21:55.550
it can be a little weird on that.

400
00:21:55.550 --> 00:21:58.922
So, and that's also another thing of
where, if you didn't want people to see

401
00:21:58.922 --> 00:22:01.954
that kind of picture and picture and
picture, you could hide it down.

402
00:22:01.954 --> 00:22:06.864
But it does live back in this little
button as you share out your different

403
00:22:06.864 --> 00:22:07.600
content.

404
00:22:07.600 --> 00:22:12.040
So I'm going to come back into here,
no I'm going to come up here and I'm

405
00:22:12.040 --> 00:22:15.210
going to stop sharing with you, because I
was the one that shared with you, Ronnie.

406
00:22:15.210 --> 00:22:18.630
So I will stop that and
back into our regular chat.

407
00:22:18.630 --> 00:22:24.840
Now, everything that we just did,
you can do with just a single window.

408
00:22:24.840 --> 00:22:27.530
Maybe I don't want them
seeing my whole desktop.

409
00:22:27.530 --> 00:22:31.730
Maybe I'll pull up Notepad again and
bring this up.

410
00:22:31.730 --> 00:22:35.120
And this is the only thing
I want Ronnie to see.

411
00:22:35.120 --> 00:22:40.110
I do not want him to see all my
other things on my computer.

412
00:22:40.110 --> 00:22:45.000
So I can share out just one window for
him.

413
00:22:46.010 --> 00:22:49.400
In our chat, if I come back over here,
share a window,

414
00:22:51.280 --> 00:22:55.580
it's gonna ask me for
which application do I want to share.

415
00:22:55.580 --> 00:22:59.524
So if I had Internet Explorer,
maybe Word, Excel,

416
00:22:59.524 --> 00:23:02.583
any application opened on my computer.

417
00:23:02.583 --> 00:23:04.380
It's gonna ask me which one to do it.

418
00:23:04.380 --> 00:23:07.270
I only have one right now,
just to make it a little easier.

419
00:23:07.270 --> 00:23:10.610
So you click the one that you want,
you get the little blue box around it.

420
00:23:10.610 --> 00:23:14.200
Notice that when I didn't click on it,
the share doesn't populate.

421
00:23:14.200 --> 00:23:15.620
So you gotta make sure you click on that.

422
00:23:15.620 --> 00:23:17.920
Click Share, and it does say,

423
00:23:17.920 --> 00:23:19.900
hey, everyone's gonna see
the program you opened.

424
00:23:19.900 --> 00:23:22.640
But it does say something about Windows 8.

425
00:23:22.640 --> 00:23:26.207
And it says that you might actually
still be able to see your desktop, so

426
00:23:26.207 --> 00:23:30.140
just in case you're on Windows 8,
nice little FYI there.

427
00:23:30.140 --> 00:23:34.790
Click OK, and now let me go ahead and
move this over.

428
00:23:34.790 --> 00:23:36.520
Sorry, ooh, come here, there it is.

429
00:23:37.670 --> 00:23:40.110
Come on, there, you can do it [LAUGH].

430
00:23:40.110 --> 00:23:44.740
So now you can see that it's got that
same share orange bar a little bit.

431
00:23:44.740 --> 00:23:46.591
It's a little bit more orange than yellow.

432
00:23:46.591 --> 00:23:48.179
I thought it was a little
bit more yellow last time.

433
00:23:48.179 --> 00:23:50.410
So you can see right here
that I am sharing it.

434
00:23:50.410 --> 00:23:52.859
I still have the same sharing options.

435
00:23:52.859 --> 00:23:56.266
I can give control He can request control,
so

436
00:23:56.266 --> 00:24:01.200
everything's the same way that
we have in sharing your desktop,

437
00:24:01.200 --> 00:24:06.000
it's just what they can see and
what they can't see.

438
00:24:06.000 --> 00:24:09.950
One thing to notice though,
if I brought in,

439
00:24:09.950 --> 00:24:14.610
let's say like this chat or anything, you
see a big black box in that area, right?

440
00:24:14.610 --> 00:24:15.230
>> I do.

441
00:24:15.230 --> 00:24:21.360
>> Yes, so he is seeing anything that
you overlap in this sharing area.

442
00:24:21.360 --> 00:24:23.170
It doesn't actually show up.

443
00:24:23.170 --> 00:24:25.450
It just shows us black area.

444
00:24:25.450 --> 00:24:26.470
So why don't we do this?

445
00:24:26.470 --> 00:24:27.881
I'm gonna stop sharing.

446
00:24:27.881 --> 00:24:30.564
And Ronnie, just so
they can see the end result,

447
00:24:30.564 --> 00:24:33.260
why don't you share a notepad with me,
please.

448
00:24:33.260 --> 00:24:34.140
>> Sounds good.

449
00:24:34.140 --> 00:24:39.026
>> All right, and I will eagerly

450
00:24:39.026 --> 00:24:44.506
await your share request [LAUGH].

451
00:24:44.506 --> 00:24:49.070
There we go, so
now I am sharing, he is typing.

452
00:24:49.070 --> 00:24:55.310
I can see everything and he'll move
something else into that area so

453
00:24:55.310 --> 00:25:00.460
you guys can see the Black box,
goodness, there it goes.

454
00:25:00.460 --> 00:25:04.700
[LAUGH] So yeah, see he's moving
the chat window right in there.

455
00:25:04.700 --> 00:25:08.040
So I don't see and
that's a nice thing to know is that,

456
00:25:08.040 --> 00:25:12.410
they're not seeing
the content of that window.

457
00:25:12.410 --> 00:25:18.300
They're just seeing it black cuz you've
only said to share out the window.

458
00:25:18.300 --> 00:25:20.260
Not the whole space.

459
00:25:20.260 --> 00:25:23.470
So in case you ever see that,
just maybe chat over and be like,

460
00:25:23.470 --> 00:25:25.720
hey can you move that other
thing out of the way?

461
00:25:25.720 --> 00:25:28.110
I can't see things and so on, so forth.

462
00:25:28.110 --> 00:25:30.770
And that's one way that we
can go ahead and do that.

463
00:25:30.770 --> 00:25:35.776
So I believe that is everything
that I wanted to descri-.

464
00:25:35.776 --> 00:25:40.280
There is one small little thing,
let me go ahead and I'll show you guys.

465
00:25:40.280 --> 00:25:43.800
In case you get a notification
as you see down here,

466
00:25:43.800 --> 00:25:47.090
it says, Ronnie wants to start sharing.

467
00:25:47.090 --> 00:25:47.955
Wait, what?

468
00:25:47.955 --> 00:25:51.960
[LAUGH] This is just one of those things
that's gonna pop up and I just ignored it.

469
00:25:51.960 --> 00:25:57.100
So he's gonna get an ignore message from
me that says, You know it didn't happen.

470
00:25:57.100 --> 00:25:58.290
The call didn't happen.

471
00:25:58.290 --> 00:26:03.710
What happened there is he went ahead and
started a chat with me.

472
00:26:03.710 --> 00:26:07.600
But he started sharing right away.

473
00:26:07.600 --> 00:26:12.780
He went ahead and maybe opened up
a white board or shared his desktop

474
00:26:12.780 --> 00:26:18.230
with me before he even sent the first chat
or the first like hey how's it going.

475
00:26:18.230 --> 00:26:23.190
So I get a notification if there's, I
don't know what he wants to share with me.

476
00:26:23.190 --> 00:26:26.510
So it might deter people
from clicking on that,

477
00:26:26.510 --> 00:26:29.810
especially if it's somebody you
don't talk to a lot of times.

478
00:26:29.810 --> 00:26:33.970
To where it's like hmm, and hopefully
with our end user security in mind,

479
00:26:33.970 --> 00:26:36.380
you don't want to accept things
from people you don't know.

480
00:26:36.380 --> 00:26:41.570
Or accept a sharing request or
anything that You might not understand, so

481
00:26:41.570 --> 00:26:43.090
just be aware that you
might want to go ahead and

482
00:26:43.090 --> 00:26:46.570
establish a conversation first,
in a sense.

483
00:26:46.570 --> 00:26:49.530
Hey, chat, video call, or audio call.

484
00:26:49.530 --> 00:26:51.990
Hey, I'm gonna stream my screen, okay?

485
00:26:51.990 --> 00:26:55.770
Great, so
establish the conversation first.

486
00:26:55.770 --> 00:26:59.040
And then go ahead and share your content
out because sometimes that little

487
00:26:59.040 --> 00:27:01.130
notification might scare people off.

488
00:27:01.130 --> 00:27:03.060
So I just wanted to show you that.

489
00:27:03.060 --> 00:27:05.340
>> Good etiquette,
more than anything else here.

490
00:27:05.340 --> 00:27:06.038
>> Definitely.

491
00:27:06.038 --> 00:27:08.100
>> All right, Vonne,
well, thank you again for

492
00:27:08.100 --> 00:27:12.270
helping us to understand a little bit more
about sharing our desktop or a window.

493
00:27:12.270 --> 00:27:15.250
To help us during those times of
collaboration when we need to,

494
00:27:15.250 --> 00:27:19.120
or demonstrate something to anybody
that's actually watching or

495
00:27:19.120 --> 00:27:20.860
who we choose to as well.

496
00:27:20.860 --> 00:27:24.850
This is a great feature that can help us
to make our collaborations a lot more

497
00:27:24.850 --> 00:27:27.740
effective instead of just trying
to talk everybody through it or

498
00:27:27.740 --> 00:27:30.240
type in everything that
somebody needs to know.

499
00:27:30.240 --> 00:27:33.940
Well, this is a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

500
00:27:33.940 --> 00:27:38.088
Signing off our Office ProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

501
00:27:38.088 --> 00:27:39.190
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

502
00:27:39.190 --> 00:27:42.370
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Skype for Business shows.

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Ronnie show how to use the whiteboard in Skype for Business. They demonstrate the different tools in the whiteboard, how to save as an image, and how to manage multiple whiteboards.
episodes.title: Use the Whiteboard
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.021 --> 00:00:01.341
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:01.341 --> 00:00:02.943
[SOUND]

3
00:00:02.943 --> 00:00:03.683
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:03.683 --> 00:00:07.757
[SOUND]

5
00:00:12.054 --> 00:00:15.178
Welcome to another great episode
right here on OFFICEPRO.TV.

6
00:00:15.178 --> 00:00:18.941
You're watching the Skype for
Business show, I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:18.941 --> 00:00:22.952
And today, we're actually gonna
see how to use the Whiteboard.

8
00:00:22.952 --> 00:00:27.381
And here to help us out is gonna be,
of course, the OFFICEPRO luminary herself,

9
00:00:27.381 --> 00:00:28.172
Vonne Smith.

10
00:00:28.172 --> 00:00:29.527
Vonne, welcome back to the show.

11
00:00:29.527 --> 00:00:32.351
>> Well, thank you for having me, I feel
glowing right now, thank you, Ronnie.

12
00:00:32.351 --> 00:00:33.674
>> That is because you are glowing, Vonne.

13
00:00:33.674 --> 00:00:35.283
>> [LAUGH]
>> So here it is,

14
00:00:35.283 --> 00:00:39.241
we've already taken a look a lot in our
series so far, in Skype for Business.

15
00:00:39.241 --> 00:00:42.146
We've talked about instant messaging and,
of course,

16
00:00:42.146 --> 00:00:44.211
the audio calls that we've been doing.

17
00:00:44.211 --> 00:00:49.037
All of these are good utilities, and most
of us are fairly familiar with doing that.

18
00:00:49.037 --> 00:00:53.729
But we probably didn't even know that this
tool existed in Skype for Business if we

19
00:00:53.729 --> 00:00:57.608
haven't done anything besides IM or
using an audio call like that.

20
00:00:57.608 --> 00:01:01.634
>> Yeah, and the other thing about
the Whiteboard, it's kind of hidden,

21
00:01:01.634 --> 00:01:04.210
it's in the More button
in the Share Content.

22
00:01:04.210 --> 00:01:07.944
And so if, like you're saying,
if all you've really ever done is chat,

23
00:01:07.944 --> 00:01:09.765
you might not have even found this.

24
00:01:09.765 --> 00:01:13.892
And we are in the collaboration,
or the collaborate topic area,

25
00:01:13.892 --> 00:01:16.526
where we're sharing different things.

26
00:01:16.526 --> 00:01:19.745
And so sharing and
using a Whiteboard is part of that.

27
00:01:19.745 --> 00:01:24.648
Because sometimes you need to get your
point across a little bit better than just

28
00:01:24.648 --> 00:01:27.077
talking about it or chatting about it.

29
00:01:27.077 --> 00:01:30.518
And I know as instructors
we tend to always,

30
00:01:30.518 --> 00:01:34.798
like when we're talking to
each other in a classroom.

31
00:01:34.798 --> 00:01:38.191
Let me come over to the whiteboard and
actually draw it out.

32
00:01:38.191 --> 00:01:42.334
Because it's kind of the way we
communicate as educators is,

33
00:01:42.334 --> 00:01:46.170
I need to draw a diagram,
I need to draw a picture for you.

34
00:01:46.170 --> 00:01:50.470
So we are going to go ahead and do that
right here within Skype for Business.

35
00:01:50.470 --> 00:01:53.398
Now, the thing to know
about when you go ahead and

36
00:01:53.398 --> 00:01:57.980
turn on the Whiteboard, even if we
are going to be in a two way conversation.

37
00:01:57.980 --> 00:02:02.790
Like we're going to demonstrate
using the Whiteboard as me and

38
00:02:02.790 --> 00:02:07.519
Ronnie, as our other people,
as our Joey and JT characters.

39
00:02:07.519 --> 00:02:11.337
We're going to just be in a regular
IM chat, and it's just the two of us.

40
00:02:11.337 --> 00:02:14.098
But as soon as I share out a Whiteboard,

41
00:02:14.098 --> 00:02:18.550
it automatically switches that
conversation into a meeting.

42
00:02:18.550 --> 00:02:22.025
And that's where it gets a little like,
hm, well, I'm just closing it, but

43
00:02:22.025 --> 00:02:23.615
it's asking me to end the meeting.

44
00:02:23.615 --> 00:02:28.183
Well, cuz technically you're
in an impromptu meeting.

45
00:02:28.183 --> 00:02:33.059
And so all of those different
aspects of running a meeting,

46
00:02:33.059 --> 00:02:38.042
where you talk about changing
the status of your attendees.

47
00:02:38.042 --> 00:02:43.512
Whether they're a presenter or you demote
them down into being just an attendee,

48
00:02:43.512 --> 00:02:47.171
all that meeting stuff,
those are in other episodes.

49
00:02:47.171 --> 00:02:49.787
>> Right.
>> So, this one, we're just concentrating

50
00:02:49.787 --> 00:02:53.317
on this particular tool, or
this collaboration item that you can do.

51
00:02:53.317 --> 00:02:58.132
And you can put this in an IM
conversation, a phone call, a Skype for

52
00:02:58.132 --> 00:03:00.598
Business meeting, any of those.

53
00:03:00.598 --> 00:03:02.767
Well, I guess a phone call,
if you're doing phone to phone,

54
00:03:02.767 --> 00:03:04.282
you can't really use a whiteboard [LAUGH].

55
00:03:04.282 --> 00:03:08.676
So I guess we'll do a Skype
client communication.

56
00:03:08.676 --> 00:03:12.509
So just kinda throwing that out there,
so you know that that's gonna happen.

>> This might be as good as we get right

So if I go ahead and save it,

And then you have OneDrive in

[LAUGH] So I'll just keep it on

Down at the bottom I need to scroll

Manage content.

00:18:36.240 --> 00:18:39.605
So if I come back down here all that

Whiteboard1 is still here, come back in.

I want to switch back over

I can click on this and I can start

So I don't want you to think

All right, so I think that's about

So let's talk about the roles for

Justin, who I almost said Joey,

Mine just turns to, instead of stop

So we would be like co-presenters,

>> Vonne, the very useful thing about

And they still had to

They can simply at that point say,

Without having to wonder,

So it allows us to do that and

But having this ability, right, is

Because a lot of times,

We think about chatting, we think about

But we hardly think about

00:21:10.720 --> 00:21:13.970

00:21:13.970 --> 00:21:16.830
It gives you at least

It would probably work better

But overall though, you see some

So take advantage of it when

All right, so Vonne,

>> The only last part would

Okay, I am ready to go ahead and stop all

So if we come back into my computer.

00:21:41.540 --> 00:21:47.730
We can stop the sharing, that's fine, but

So if I try to close this, and

If I just close the chat,
cuz you think we're just each other,

it's gonna give you that whole,

00:21:59.520 --> 00:22:02.120
And this is something that I know we've

00:22:04.790 --> 00:22:05.670

I have to end because it basically

00:22:10.910 --> 00:22:11.870

00:22:14.920 --> 00:22:15.510

And that might be another

I thought Joey and

00:23:06.030 --> 00:23:10.161
I'm not ready to talk to anybody else and

[LAUGH] So just always start with

Tune IM, terming an audio call and

Don't start all of this stuff before you

00:23:29.383 --> 00:23:30.590
>> [LAUGH]
>> Cuz it can be misleading.

00:23:30.590 --> 00:23:33.820
I think we talked about that in the shared

I don't wanna talk to

I don't wanna go ahead and get this

00:23:44.370 --> 00:23:45.840
something.

446
00:23:45.840 --> 00:23:49.931
So just establish your conversation
first and then go ahead and

00:23:49.931 --> 00:23:52.490

448
00:23:53.560 --> 00:23:57.190
>> Now Vonne, that's a really good point

A message that is just unsolicitated, so

00:24:06.720 --> 00:24:11.280

00:24:11.280 --> 00:24:15.040

>> It's actually a pretty big one.

00:24:16.620 --> 00:24:19.480
>> Okay.
>> So any of these collaboration tool that

00:24:19.480 --> 00:24:25.180

00:24:25.180 --> 00:24:27.150
We're doing it from the PC angle.

458

Well, we can go ahead and use whiteboards,
and the PowerPoints, and all that.

459
00:24:31.560 --> 00:24:35.910
But if you're talking to somebody on
the other end that is using the Skype for

460
00:24:35.910 --> 00:24:38.400
Business client on a Mac.

00:24:38.400 --> 00:24:40.990
They're not gonna be able to see that,
they're not gonna see the whiteboard,

00:24:40.990 --> 00:24:42.660
they're not gonna be able

00:24:42.660 --> 00:24:46.210
Doesn't matter what role they have,

almost all of this tools in

465
00:24:53.430 --> 00:24:54.230
They can't do it.

466

It's just not built into

467

They can do screen shares or

468
00:25:00.860 --> 00:25:02.580
They can't do individual windows, okay?

469
00:25:02.580 --> 00:25:06.030
And I think I actually left that

470
00:25:06.030 --> 00:25:08.700
but just be very aware of that.

471
00:25:08.700 --> 00:25:14.140
The person on the other end if they don't
have a PC a lot of stuff is null and

472
00:25:14.140 --> 00:25:15.000
void to them.

473
00:25:15.000 --> 00:25:20.160
So that's kinda throws a wrench in
some of this collaboration tools.

474
00:25:20.160 --> 00:25:21.680
So just wanna point that up.

475
00:25:21.680 --> 00:25:25.000
>> That's a good thing to
actually remember with this

476
00:25:25.000 --> 00:25:29.200
idea that we have is not nice to think
there's gonna be a spread across the board

477
00:25:29.200 --> 00:25:31.330
regardless of what
machine that you are on.

478
00:25:31.330 --> 00:25:34.230
Really all these tools that we are talking
about in the detailed Vonne has talked

479
00:25:34.230 --> 00:25:39.460
about, is gonna sent the only work very
well inside of a Windows environment.

480
00:25:39.460 --> 00:25:41.450
So make sure you remember that as well.

481
00:25:41.450 --> 00:25:44.500
That's a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

482
00:25:44.500 --> 00:25:48.410
Signing off of OfficePro TV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

484
00:25:49.340 --> 00:25:52.611
>> Stay tuned right here for
