00:14:45.082 --> 00:14:50.176
what everybody else is seeing
as the presenter's view.

241
00:14:50.176 --> 00:14:55.015
So that's why you can see up at the top
now, I have a button that says,

242
00:14:55.015 --> 00:14:57.650
Return to Presenter's View.

243
00:14:57.650 --> 00:15:05.480
If I click on that, this is the particular
slide that Ronnie/Justin is on.

244
00:15:05.480 --> 00:15:09.554
So you can see,
as somebody that is a co-presenter, or

245
00:15:09.554 --> 00:15:13.580
the non-organizer, but
still in a presenter roll.

246
00:15:13.580 --> 00:15:16.710
I can do some other things,
like if he's on this slide,

247
00:15:16.710 --> 00:15:18.460
he's on the Phone Call slide.

248
00:15:18.460 --> 00:15:22.560
Let's say that I know that
this particular slide,

249
00:15:22.560 --> 00:15:24.850
we're gonna need to do some annotation.

250
00:15:24.850 --> 00:15:27.110
So I'm gonna come up here,
I'm privately viewing,

251
00:15:27.110 --> 00:15:29.530
now I got a second one
cuz I'm doing it again.

252
00:15:29.530 --> 00:15:34.770
I can come up here, and
I can make an annotation,

253
00:15:34.770 --> 00:15:37.160
just draw a star,
[LAUGH] on this particular one.

254
00:15:37.160 --> 00:15:41.265
If I go to the Presenter's View,
he's still on the Phone Call, and

255
00:15:41.265 --> 00:15:45.597
see he's drawing it up, so
everybody else is seeing what he's doing.

256
00:15:45.597 --> 00:15:51.810
When Ronnie advances to the next slide,
it's going to show the annotations that I,

257
00:15:51.810 --> 00:15:56.110
as that second presenter,
went ahead and marked up on it.

258
00:15:56.110 --> 00:16:01.720
So that's why you see this Privately
viewing coming up here at the bottom,

259
00:16:01.720 --> 00:16:07.152
because I can do things to this
PowerPoint presentation that are just for

260
00:16:07.152 --> 00:16:08.844
what I'm looking at,

261
00:16:08.844 --> 00:16:14.180
not everybody else in the room which
I think is kinda cool actually.

262
00:16:14.180 --> 00:16:17.370
So as like a helper through all of this,

263
00:16:17.370 --> 00:16:22.190
I know what that means now and
what I can do to control it.

264
00:16:22.190 --> 00:16:25.100
And if I return back, the other
thing is if I wanted to go ahead and

265
00:16:25.100 --> 00:16:26.690
take over as the presenter.

266
00:16:26.690 --> 00:16:32.100
It's like, okay, so now Joey back to you,
then I unmute my microphone and say, okay

267
00:16:32.100 --> 00:16:36.380
great, so let me go ahead and show you
where we need to go next, and everything.

268
00:16:36.380 --> 00:16:40.620
Notice that my button up at
the top says Stop Sharing,

269
00:16:40.620 --> 00:16:45.580
because I don't have the viewing
privately anymore, now I could,

270
00:16:45.580 --> 00:16:49.301
and I don't know how many
of you all catched that.

271
00:16:49.301 --> 00:16:53.180
But down here, I believe when
I go into the Manage Content,

272
00:16:53.180 --> 00:16:59.248
there was another in the more,
I'm not [LAUGH] the organizer any more.

273
00:16:59.248 --> 00:17:04.070
[LAUGH] But as the organizer
there is a button that says,

274
00:17:04.070 --> 00:17:07.820
view privately, in that option there,
in the Manage Content.

275
00:17:07.820 --> 00:17:10.586
And that's exactly what I'm showing you,

276
00:17:10.586 --> 00:17:15.080
is that it will be private to only you and
not everybody in the room.

277
00:17:15.080 --> 00:17:19.760
Okay, so I will go ahead and you can grab
control back over there correct Ronnie?

278
00:17:19.760 --> 00:17:20.360
You can-
>> Yes.

279
00:17:20.360 --> 00:17:23.510
>> Take that and
say that you become the main presenter and

280
00:17:23.510 --> 00:17:28.440
then my buttons will come
back as the taking over and

281
00:17:28.440 --> 00:17:34.180
then viewing the Powerpoint presentation
privately if I wanted to do that.

282
00:17:35.190 --> 00:17:41.010
Wonderful, so
that's the role of a secondary presenter.

283
00:17:41.010 --> 00:17:45.260
Now the next one we're gonna show,
just so you get an idea of what

284
00:17:45.260 --> 00:17:49.495
your end users are seeing,
if you have them as attendees, okay.

285
00:17:49.495 --> 00:17:55.490
Now if you're in a company meeting,
maybe all of you are presenters and

286
00:17:55.490 --> 00:18:00.490
you've never really messed with this
before, because it's like well we can all

287
00:18:00.490 --> 00:18:03.350
do what we need to do to the PowerPoint
because we're collaborating on it.

288
00:18:03.350 --> 00:18:07.360
But if you're conducting a webinar,
then having people as attendees,

289
00:18:07.360 --> 00:18:09.820
it's always nice to see
what they're seeing.

290
00:18:09.820 --> 00:18:13.600
So if you don't mind Ronnie,
can you go ahead and demote or

291
00:18:13.600 --> 00:18:18.530
just change the role
of Joey to a attendee.

292
00:18:18.530 --> 00:18:22.592
And by the way, the way he is doing
that is over here, right clicking

293
00:18:22.592 --> 00:18:27.388
on the particular person, and then
choosing make, does it say make attendee?

294
00:18:27.388 --> 00:18:29.166
>> Let's see if I can find it here.

295
00:18:29.166 --> 00:18:31.198
>> [LAUGH] So, yeah, hover over Joey and

296
00:18:31.198 --> 00:18:34.883
then right click on his,
two finger click on that computer.

297
00:18:34.883 --> 00:18:35.581
>> Yeah, that's right.

298
00:18:35.581 --> 00:18:39.473
>> He's using my MacBook and
his old MacBook, there you go.

299
00:18:39.473 --> 00:18:43.597
[LAUGH] So you can see that now Joey,
me I'm an attendee, I can see it in

300
00:18:43.597 --> 00:18:48.576
the participant, because that's just the
pain I can do that as a participant, but

301
00:18:48.576 --> 00:18:52.371
also there's hey, you're an attendee,
sit back and enjoy.

302
00:18:52.371 --> 00:18:55.259
Cool, so
I don't have any of those buttons,

303
00:18:55.259 --> 00:18:58.455
I can't control anything,
I can't click on it.

304
00:18:58.455 --> 00:19:03.073
I was actually thinking, yes,
you can go into full screen, so

305
00:19:03.073 --> 00:19:06.350
you can take that into consideration.

306
00:19:06.350 --> 00:19:09.230
I thought you could do it by double
clicking but it looks like as attendee,

307
00:19:09.230 --> 00:19:11.760
you can't do that, but
at least you know you have the button.

308
00:19:11.760 --> 00:19:13.150
So that's the biggest thing,

309
00:19:14.660 --> 00:19:17.548
you might have been able to
maybe figure that out like.

310
00:19:17.548 --> 00:19:19.970
Hopefully attendees can't do anything,
that's true.

311
00:19:19.970 --> 00:19:24.201
So [LAUGH] but we do talk more about
all the roles of the attendees, and

312
00:19:24.201 --> 00:19:29.118
what you can do as an organizer to control
what the attendees can and cannot do.

313
00:19:29.118 --> 00:19:31.312
Can they chat,
can they turn on their video?

314
00:19:31.312 --> 00:19:35.276
Cuz you probably don't want people just
popping up videos all the time if you're

315
00:19:35.276 --> 00:19:37.034
trying to do a major presentation.

316
00:19:37.034 --> 00:19:41.795
[LAUGH] So just make sure you know all
about how to control your meetings while

317
00:19:41.795 --> 00:19:46.518
you're running things, and make sure
you keep your attendees in check.

318
00:19:46.518 --> 00:19:52.070
So [LAUGH] and that's really all I
have for PowerPoint presentations.

319
00:19:52.070 --> 00:19:56.290
I would say it's mostly intuitive,
I think the secondary

320
00:19:56.290 --> 00:20:00.924
presenter thing can get a little weird
in why I'm seeing this differently, and

321
00:20:00.924 --> 00:20:03.440
like, gosh,
are they seeing me advance the slides.

322
00:20:03.440 --> 00:20:08.040
Nope, you're good, as long as you well,
know what you're doing, so, pretty good.

323
00:20:08.040 --> 00:20:10.880
>> All right Vonne, well,
thank you for helping us out here,

324
00:20:10.880 --> 00:20:12.990
especially with working with PowerPoint.

325
00:20:12.990 --> 00:20:15.990
It's easy enough to understand
why we do PowerPoints, but

326
00:20:15.990 --> 00:20:18.710
the ability to use something
like Skype for Business

327
00:20:18.710 --> 00:20:22.930
to allow us to share the PowerPoint
presentation, not only to share it, but

328
00:20:22.930 --> 00:20:26.794
allow somebody else to also present
it is a very powerful feature.

329
00:20:26.794 --> 00:20:30.720
And being able to handoff and doing
the annotations, really do help make your

330
00:20:30.720 --> 00:20:34.980
PowerPoint presentation much more
effective over a greater distance as well.

331
00:20:34.980 --> 00:20:37.860
And it's a tool that we should
actually be very interested in,

332
00:20:37.860 --> 00:20:40.050
if we do tend to lead a lot of meetings.

333
00:20:40.050 --> 00:20:42.820
But that's a great place for
us to also sign off then.

334
00:20:42.820 --> 00:20:46.200
For OfficeProTV I'm your host,
Ronnie Wong.

335
00:20:46.200 --> 00:20:47.130
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

336
00:20:47.130 --> 00:20:50.236
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Skype for Business episodes.

337
00:20:50.236 --> 00:20:55.760
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne show to engage attendees in a meeting by conducting polls.  They show demonstrate how to add poll questions, open and close polls, share the results to attendees, and save poll results.
episodes.title: Conduct a Poll
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.047 --> 00:00:14.795
Welcome to another great episode
right here on OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:14.795 --> 00:00:18.170
You're watching the Skype for
Business Show.

4
00:00:18.170 --> 00:00:19.700
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:19.700 --> 00:00:24.560
And today, we're gonna be showing you how
to conduct a poll in Skype for Business.

6
00:00:24.560 --> 00:00:30.890
And here to help us once again is gonna
be our Office Pro virtuoso herself,

7
00:00:30.890 --> 00:00:31.540
Miss Vonne Smith.

8
00:00:31.540 --> 00:00:32.555
Vonne welcome back to the show.

9
00:00:32.555 --> 00:00:34.220
>> I'm so glad to be here.

10
00:00:34.220 --> 00:00:35.241
Always so much fun with you Ronnie.

11
00:00:35.241 --> 00:00:35.890
>> All right.

12
00:00:35.890 --> 00:00:40.176
So Vonne, here it is,
what is this idea of a poll?

13
00:00:40.176 --> 00:00:44.466
We've already talked about using
a Whiteboard, we've also of course shared

14
00:00:44.466 --> 00:00:48.600
PowerPoints and this is part of
a collaboration, what is this about?

15
00:00:48.600 --> 00:00:52.323
>> Well it's just like what you
would consider taking a poll or

16
00:00:52.323 --> 00:00:55.605
conducting a poll,
being part of a survey, right?

17
00:00:55.605 --> 00:00:58.418
It's like you have a question,
who here likes ice cream?

18
00:00:58.418 --> 00:00:59.685
Me.

19
00:00:59.685 --> 00:01:03.383
[LAUGH] And then the question be yes or
no or maybe,

20
00:01:03.383 --> 00:01:06.722
what is your favorite
flavor of ice cream and

21
00:01:06.722 --> 00:01:12.250
then you ahead and
says well 55% of all people say chocolate.

22
00:01:12.250 --> 00:01:15.383
Just totally making it up, but
you have that whole idea of,

23
00:01:15.383 --> 00:01:19.471
there's a certain percentage of people
who answered the question this way.

24
00:01:19.471 --> 00:01:24.844
And so if you think about in a meeting,
that can be a great way to interact and

25
00:01:24.844 --> 00:01:30.135
collaborate with your users and
the attendees of your meeting, all right

26
00:01:30.135 --> 00:01:35.530
what do you think is the best way that
we should answer this team question?

27
00:01:35.530 --> 00:01:40.137
I am totally making things up, but you get
the idea of being able to kinda throw it

28
00:01:40.137 --> 00:01:45.150
out to them, then to participate and
then they see all the answers.

29
00:01:45.150 --> 00:01:47.090
Now that's something that you,

30
00:01:47.090 --> 00:01:50.788
as the organizer of the meeting,
you're gonna need to know how to control.

31
00:01:50.788 --> 00:01:54.660
So that's what we're here to show you,
is how to control all of that and

32
00:01:54.660 --> 00:01:55.870
then we'll flip it over and

33
00:01:55.870 --> 00:02:01.160
then show you how the attendees see
it on the other side of the coin.

34
00:02:01.160 --> 00:02:03.325
And then how to answer the question
because it's always good

35
00:02:03.325 --> 00:02:04.051
to know both sides.

36
00:02:04.051 --> 00:02:08.726
If you're the only one that's ever going
to organize, you need to know what

37
00:02:08.726 --> 00:02:13.036
your end users see to be able to just
really understand everything that

38
00:02:13.036 --> 00:02:17.602
you're doing in a meeting and
to really like conduct a seamless meeting.

39
00:02:17.602 --> 00:02:19.600
So it's not like, oops,
I clicked the wrong button.

40
00:02:19.600 --> 00:02:24.733
And then I'm like, wait, I do that all
time in these shows [LAUGH] but you get

41
00:02:24.733 --> 00:02:30.450
the idea of making sure that you know
how to use all of these different tools.

42
00:02:30.450 --> 00:02:32.140
So, that's what we're going to do today,
Ronnie.

43
00:02:32.140 --> 00:02:35.770
All right, Vonne, it sounds like a good
way also to keep our people that are in

44
00:02:35.770 --> 00:02:40.360
this meeting engaged by asking them these
types of questions every once in awhile.

45
00:02:40.360 --> 00:02:44.120
Or if you really needed the feedback from
them so that you knew what to proceed on.

46
00:02:44.120 --> 00:02:47.373
So Vonne, show us how we're gonna
start doing something like this.

47
00:02:47.373 --> 00:02:50.845
>> All right, well we have Joey's
computer all ready to go and

48
00:02:50.845 --> 00:02:53.385
I've actually got a group chat going.

49
00:02:53.385 --> 00:02:56.542
So we're still saying in chat cuz
we're not turning on videos or

50
00:02:56.542 --> 00:02:58.585
audios or anything like that.

51
00:02:58.585 --> 00:03:03.215
And I actually have a couple of people in
the room, I have me as the organizer and

52
00:03:03.215 --> 00:03:07.414
I also have Justin and
we have our good friends Marisha and

53
00:03:07.414 --> 00:03:08.840
Renee in the room as well.

54
00:03:08.840 --> 00:03:13.835
But do know, this is a meeting and with
these roles in our meetings I have put

55
00:03:13.835 --> 00:03:17.022
everybody else besides
myself as an attendee.

56
00:03:17.022 --> 00:03:21.920
Now this is something good to where
they're not going to be able to control

57
00:03:21.920 --> 00:03:27.360
the polls and I want them to see it as
an attendee and not as a presenter status.

58
00:03:27.360 --> 00:03:29.870
So that's something to know
about with meetings and

59
00:03:29.870 --> 00:03:32.130
then to control how that all works.

60
00:03:32.130 --> 00:03:36.870
I'm also just for fun I'm going to turn
off their videos, I know my girls and

61
00:03:36.870 --> 00:03:40.886
they're probably gonna be like,
I'm not coming on the video.

62
00:03:40.886 --> 00:03:43.653
Well at least not today,
cuz I haven't warned them and

63
00:03:43.653 --> 00:03:46.550
we know about our hair washing
schedule there, Ronnie.

64
00:03:46.550 --> 00:03:49.550
So well that might be
another time [LAUGH].

65
00:03:49.550 --> 00:03:54.950
So I'm going to say, thank you for coming.

66
00:03:54.950 --> 00:04:00.590
And we will say, we are going

67
00:04:00.590 --> 00:04:06.522
to conduct a poll in a few seconds.

68
00:04:06.522 --> 00:04:10.490
Just to let them know that
this is coming in our chat.

69
00:04:10.490 --> 00:04:16.030
So now, how do I go ahead and
start this poll?

70
00:04:16.030 --> 00:04:20.455
It's in our share content and
then we go to our More,

71
00:04:20.455 --> 00:04:26.805
every time I start this I'm like wait,
where, it's in the More section.

72
00:04:26.805 --> 00:04:31.040
[LAUGH] All right, so there we go,
we've got our poll right there.

73
00:04:31.040 --> 00:04:33.920
Now, this is something that I'm
creating on the fly, all right?

74
00:04:33.920 --> 00:04:36.454
This is where I'm coming into this poll,

75
00:04:36.454 --> 00:04:40.940
now nothing that I'm doing right now
is being shown on the their screens.

76
00:04:40.940 --> 00:04:44.280
So take into consideration,
you might not want to,

77
00:04:44.280 --> 00:04:48.150
especially if you have lengthy answers
that you need to have them choose from,

78
00:04:48.150 --> 00:04:50.090
you're gonna wanna do this beforehand.

79
00:04:50.090 --> 00:04:52.790
So in a scheduled meeting where you

80
00:04:52.790 --> 00:04:55.820
are gonna go into the meeting
room before everybody gets there,

81
00:04:55.820 --> 00:04:59.850
you're gonna control how people are in
the lobby and not in there just yet.

82
00:04:59.850 --> 00:05:03.220
You go ahead and
preload all of your poll questions,

83
00:05:03.220 --> 00:05:05.610
because just like any
of our shared content,

84
00:05:05.610 --> 00:05:09.640
it's gonna go into the managed content and
then you can be able to pull those

85
00:05:09.640 --> 00:05:15.740
questions up when you're ready to do that
particular poll within your presentation.

86
00:05:15.740 --> 00:05:19.295
And you don't have to have them waiting
while you're typing all that out.

87
00:05:19.295 --> 00:05:22.295
So definitely take note of that and
if you don't know what I'm talking about,

88
00:05:22.295 --> 00:05:26.675
definitely go back over to some of our
meeting episodes and the content so

89
00:05:26.675 --> 00:05:27.627
you can understand that.

90
00:05:27.627 --> 00:05:31.955
So we're just gonna do
something really simple like,

91
00:05:31.955 --> 00:05:36.764
what is your favorite animal,
always gotta go with animal.

92
00:05:36.764 --> 00:05:39.052
I know we talked about ice cream,
we'll do that next, all right?

93
00:05:39.052 --> 00:05:39.910
>> Okay.

94
00:05:39.910 --> 00:05:45.540
>> So we'll go with, I'm gonna go
with cats and then we'll go with dog,

95
00:05:45.540 --> 00:05:51.660
we'll go with bunny and we'll go with
gremlin, we'll go with that so [LAUGH].

96
00:05:51.660 --> 00:05:52.598
>> All right.

97
00:05:52.598 --> 00:05:55.649
>> So we'll have a gremlin and
I'm gonna go ahead and click create.

98
00:05:57.070 --> 00:06:00.095
And then,
what happens is the stage pops up and

99
00:06:00.095 --> 00:06:03.752
now all of my attendees
are seeing what is on the screen.

100
00:06:03.752 --> 00:06:06.220
It says, what is your favorite animal?

101
00:06:06.220 --> 00:06:08.890
And then you can see,
again, I'm the presenter,

102
00:06:08.890 --> 00:06:13.710
I am the organizer, I can see people
are starting to answer the question.

103
00:06:13.710 --> 00:06:17.160
Now by default the poll is open, so

104
00:06:17.160 --> 00:06:21.900
that means that everybody can see
this as soon as I pop this up.

105
00:06:21.900 --> 00:06:23.650
And then the other thing to notice,
by default,

106
00:06:23.650 --> 00:06:26.760
is that the results are hidden
from the attendees.

107
00:06:26.760 --> 00:06:31.170
So the attendees are answering
the question right now and

108
00:06:31.170 --> 00:06:34.362
this is also something like when
you're in the presentation,

109
00:06:34.362 --> 00:06:35.360
you're probably gonna go ahead and

110
00:06:35.360 --> 00:06:39.970
say, all right take the next 30 seconds
to go ahead and answer these questions,

111
00:06:39.970 --> 00:06:43.830
really think about it all that thing and
you're seeing the results come in.

112
00:06:43.830 --> 00:06:46.120
I can see that I've had
three people respond to me,

113
00:06:46.120 --> 00:06:48.380
I have three people in the room,
so it's awesome.

114
00:06:48.380 --> 00:06:52.290
So everyone ahead and
answered my question so that's lovely.

115
00:06:52.290 --> 00:06:56.880
Now down here at the bottom,
you have the poll actions and

116
00:06:56.880 --> 00:07:01.980
the poll actions, these are things that
you're going to control as the organizer.

117
00:07:01.980 --> 00:07:05.435
So and again,
this is that kind of practicing and

118
00:07:05.435 --> 00:07:10.495
knowing what all these things do to
make that seamless presentation and

119
00:07:10.495 --> 00:07:14.205
keep this engagement,
